title: What is the occult symbolism behind transformation in nature and the role of love in it?
first_phrase: In this text, the author explores the concept of love and transformation in nature. They delve into the symbolism of the sun, moon, and mercury representing active, passive, and simultaneous energy, respectively. The transformation that occurs in nature follows a constant law, leading to a change in appearance, such as water being absorbed by plants instead of rusting iron. The crisis, or destructive transformation, caused by the energy of love is present in all visible and invisible kingdoms. This includes animal appetites, where the act of crisis, or reproductive love, is a typical destroyer. The animal act of appetite, or agub in Aryan, condenses and focuses all the energy, senses, and will of the creature onto the desired object. The result is a potent attraction that precedes physical enjoyment.

Nelle forme animali la crisi stessa e' un'appetenza che e' un assorbimento di un essere animale in un altro essere di una forma animale in un'altra forma o stato transitorio. Quindi (tutti gli stati di appetenza in natura sono stati distruttori (o trasformatori) di forme; il tipico distruttore e' l'atto puramente di crisi (Amore) riproduttiva. Questi atti di appetenza (la forma per es.) qualunque sia il grado dell'animale, dal serpe all'uomo, sono detti con una parola ariana agub, che vuol dire demente, cioè' atti in cui tutto l'essere animale appetente o innamorata si condensa in volontà', in forza, in sensi, in desiderio sulla cosa a l'essere appetito. Questa condensazione diventa oggettiva, l'essere appetente, condensandosi si esternizza e tocca, e penetra, e trafigge la cosa appetita, facendovi una sattrazione prima che materialmente la goda e la assapori.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the natural states of desire and appetite, such as love and reproduction, have the power to transform or destroy forms, as seen in animals and even in humans. This transformative power can be harnessed and manipulated by human magicians, as well as experienced in the physical act of love. Ultimately, all forms of consumption and transformation in nature, whether in eating or sexuality, involve a kind of natural vampirism - the absorption and assimilation of one form into another.
